results.title: A Big Country: The Legend of Jimmy Governor
results.brief_description:
Episode of ABC TV series ‘A Big Country’ exploring the real life story of Jimmy Governor, as compared to his fictional counterpart, Jimmie Blacksmith, in the novel and film, ‘The Chant of Jimmie Blacksmith’. Includes interviews with author, Thomas Keneally, and film director, Fred Schepisi, on location during the making of the film.
Broadcast on ABC TV in April 1978. Reporter: Kenyon Castle. Narrator: Bob Plasto.

results.title: Be it ever so humble
results.creator_credit: Ron Iddon, John Sparkes and ABC
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Big country”.
Shot in Queensland, this film examines the development in styles of houses in Australia, from the slab hut to the contemporary brick house. Suitable for Upper Secondary-Tertiary level students.

results.title: Confidence in contact
results.creator_credit: Bill Latto and Town and Country Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Better Rugby”.
New methods of introducing and developing the techniques of tackling in rugby football. After building surprising ability and confidence in junior players, Barry John (Wales and British Lions) and Willie John McBride (Ireland and British Lions) show how the same coaching methods can be used in giving senior players complete confidence in going in for the tackle.

results.title: F.H. Greenway
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Behind the Legend”.
Introduced by Manning Clarke, the film proficiently reconstructs the story of Francis Greenway’s relationship and court case with Edward Sanderson of the N.S.W. Corps, and gives glimpses of the conditions in the colony under the Governorship of Macquarie. Written by Joanne Bean, the cast includes John Ewart as Francis Greenway and Nick Tate as Captain Sanderson.

results.title: R. O'Hara Burke
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Behind the Legend”.
Presents a dramatized reenactment of the events surrounding Robert O’Hara Burke through the memories of his friends. Aspects of his life, the Burke and Wills Expedition and his death are reconstructed. Introduced by Manning Clark and written by Thomas Keneally. Cast includes Tony Allyn as Burke, Cornelia Frances, Ian Nimmo, Richard Lupina, Don Philps, David Williams, Clive Marshall and Shirley Sunners.
